<h2><a id="user-content-questions-for-this-class" class="anchor" href="#questions-for-this-class" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>Questions for this class</h2>

<ul>
<li>Consider trying to answer the following kinds of questions:

<ul>
<li>To use the parents' heights to predict childrens' heights.</li>
<li>To try to find a parsimonious, easily described mean 
relationship between parent and children's heights.</li>
<li>To investigate the variation in childrens' heights that appears 
unrelated to parents' heights (residual variation).</li>
<li>To quantify what impact genotype information has beyond parental height in explaining child height.</li>
<li>To figure out how/whether and what assumptions are needed to
generalize findings beyond the data in question.<br></li>
<li>Why do children of very tall parents tend to be 
tall, but a little shorter than their parents and why children of very short parents tend to be short, but a little taller than their parents? (This is a famous question called 'Regression to the mean'.)</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2><a id="user-content-galtons-data" class="anchor" href="#galtons-data" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>Galton's Data</h2>

<ul>
<li>Let's look at the data first, used by Francis Galton in 1885. </li>
<li>Galton was a statistician who invented the term and concepts
of regression and correlation, founded the journal Biometrika,
and was the cousin of Charles Darwin.</li>
<li>You may need to run <code>install.packages("UsingR")</code> if the <code>UsingR</code> library is not installed.</li>
<li>Let's look at the marginal (parents disregarding children and children disregarding parents) distributions first. 

<ul>
<li>Parent distribution is all heterosexual couples.</li>
<li>Correction for gender via multiplying female heights by 1.08.</li>
<li>Overplotting is an issue from discretization.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<hr>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">UsingR</span>); data(<span class="pl-smi">galton</span>); library(<span class="pl-smi">reshape</span>); <span class="pl-smi">long</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> melt(<span class="pl-smi">galton</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> ggplot(<span class="pl-smi">long</span>, aes(<span class="pl-v">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">value</span>, <span class="pl-v">fill</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">variable</span>)) 
<span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> geom_histogram(<span class="pl-v">colour</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>black<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">binwidth</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>) 
<span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> facet_grid(. <span class="pl-k">~</span> <span class="pl-smi">variable</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">g</span></pre></div>

<hr>

<h2><a id="user-content-finding-the-middle-via-least-squares" class="anchor" href="#finding-the-middle-via-least-squares" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>Finding the middle via least squares</h2>

<ul>
<li>Consider only the children's heights. 

<ul>
<li>How could one describe the "middle"?</li>
<li>One definition, let $Y_i$ be the height of child $i$ for $i = 1, \ldots, n = 928$, then define the middle as the value of $\mu$
that minimizes $$\sum_{i=1}^n (Y_i - \mu)^2$$</li>
</ul></li>
<li>This is physical center of mass of the histrogram.</li>
<li>You might have guessed that the answer $\mu = \bar Y$.</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2><a id="user-content-experiment" class="anchor" href="#experiment" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>Experiment</h2>

<h3><a id="user-content-use-r-studios-manipulate-to-see-what-value-of-mu-minimizes-the-sum-of-the-squared-deviations" class="anchor" href="#use-r-studios-manipulate-to-see-what-value-of-mu-minimizes-the-sum-of-the-squared-deviations" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>Use R studio's manipulate to see what value of $\mu$ minimizes the sum of the squared deviations.</h3>

<pre><code>library(manipulate)
myHist &lt;- function(mu){
    mse &lt;- mean((galton$child - mu)^2)
    g &lt;- ggplot(galton, aes(x = child)) + geom_histogram(fill = "salmon", colour = "black", binwidth=1)
    g &lt;- g + geom_vline(xintercept = mu, size = 3)
    g &lt;- g + ggtitle(paste("mu = ", mu, ", MSE = ", round(mse, 2), sep = ""))
    g
}
manipulate(myHist(mu), mu = slider(62, 74, step = 0.5))
</code></pre>

<hr>

<h2><a id="user-content-the-least-squares-est-is-the-empirical-mean" class="anchor" href="#the-least-squares-est-is-the-empirical-mean" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>The least squares est. is the empirical mean</h2>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> ggplot(<span class="pl-smi">galton</span>, aes(<span class="pl-v">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">child</span>)) <span class="pl-k">+</span> geom_histogram(<span class="pl-v">fill</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>salmon<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">colour</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>black<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">binwidth</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> geom_vline(<span class="pl-v">xintercept</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> mean(<span class="pl-smi">galton</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">child</span>), <span class="pl-v">size</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">g</span></pre></div>

<hr>

<h3><a id="user-content-the-math-not-required-for-the-class-follows-as" class="anchor" href="#the-math-not-required-for-the-class-follows-as" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>The math (not required for the class) follows as:</h3>

<p>$$ 
\begin{align} 
\sum_{i=1}^n \left(Y_i - \mu\right)^2 &amp; = \
\sum_{i=1}^n \left(Y_i - \bar Y + \bar Y - \mu\right)^2 \ 
&amp; = \sum_{i=1}^n \left(Y_i - \bar Y\right)^2 + \
2 \sum_{i=1}^n \left(Y_i - \bar Y\right)  \left(\bar Y - \mu\right) +\
\sum_{i=1}^n \left(\bar Y - \mu\right)^2 \
&amp; = \sum_{i=1}^n \left(Y_i - \bar Y\right)^2 + \
2 \left(\bar Y - \mu\right) \sum_{i=1}^n \left(Y_i - \bar Y\right) +\
\sum_{i=1}^n \left(\bar Y - \mu\right)^2 \
&amp; = \sum_{i=1}^n \left(Y_i - \bar Y\right)^2 + \
2 \left(\bar Y - \mu\right)  \left(\left(\sum_{i=1}^n Y_i\right) -\
 n \bar Y\right) +\
\sum_{i=1}^n \left(\bar Y - \mu\right)^2 \
&amp; = \sum_{i=1}^n \left(Y_i - \bar Y\right)^2 + \
 \sum_{i=1}^n \left(\bar Y - \mu\right)^2\ 
&amp; \geq \sum_{i=1}^n \left(Y_i - \bar Y\right)^2 \
\end{align} 
$$</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-comparing-childrens-heights-and-their-parents-heights" class="anchor" href="#comparing-childrens-heights-and-their-parents-heights" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>Comparing childrens' heights and their parents' heights</h2>

<h2><a id="user-content-regression-through-the-origin" class="anchor" href="#regression-through-the-origin" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>Regression through the origin</h2>

<ul>
<li>Suppose that $X_i$ are the parents' heights.</li>
<li>Consider picking the slope $\beta$ that minimizes $$\sum_{i=1}^n (Y_i - X_i \beta)^2$$</li>
<li>This is exactly using the origin as a pivot point picking the
line that minimizes the sum of the squared vertical distances
of the points to the line</li>
<li>Use R studio's  manipulate function to experiment</li>
<li>Subtract the means so that the origin is the mean of the parent
and children's heights</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">y</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">galton</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">child</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> mean(<span class="pl-smi">galton</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">child</span>)

<span class="pl-smi">freqData</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> as.data.frame(table(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>, <span class="pl-smi">y</span>))

<span class="pl-smi">freqData</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">child</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> as.numeric(as.character(<span class="pl-smi">freqData</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">child</span>))
<span class="pl-smi">freqData</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">parent</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> as.numeric(as.character(<span class="pl-smi">freqData</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">parent</span>))
<span class="pl-en">myPlot</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">beta</span>){
    <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> ggplot(filter(<span class="pl-smi">freqData</span>, <span class="pl-smi">freq</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span>), aes(<span class="pl-v">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">parent</span>, <span class="pl-v">y</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">child</span>))
    <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">g</span>  <span class="pl-k">+</span> scale_size(<span class="pl-v">range</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">2</span>, <span class="pl-c1">20</span>), <span class="pl-v">guide</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>none<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span> )
    <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> geom_point(<span class="pl-v">colour</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>grey50<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, aes(<span class="pl-v">size</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">freq</span><span class="pl-k">+</span><span class="pl-c1">20</span>, <span class="pl-v">show_guide</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>))
    <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> geom_point(aes(<span class="pl-v">colour</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">freq</span>, <span class="pl-v">size</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">freq</span>))
    <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> scale_colour_gradient(<span class="pl-v">low</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>lightblue<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">high</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>white<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)                     
    <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> geom_abline(<span class="pl-v">intercept</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span>, <span class="pl-v">slope</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">beta</span>, <span class="pl-v">size</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span>)
    <span class="pl-smi">mse</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> mean( (<span class="pl-smi">y</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">beta</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> <span class="pl-smi">x</span>) <span class="pl-k">^</span><span class="pl-c1">2</span> )
    <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">g</span> <span class="pl-k">+</span> ggtitle(paste(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>beta = <span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">beta</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>mse = <span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, round(<span class="pl-smi">mse</span>, <span class="pl-c1">3</span>)))
    <span class="pl-smi">g</span>

manipulate(myPlot(<span class="pl-smi">beta</span>), <span class="pl-v">beta</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> slider(<span class="pl-c1">0.6</span>, <span class="pl-c1">1.2</span>, <span class="pl-v">step</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.02</span>))</pre></div>

<h2><a id="user-content-the-solution" class="anchor" href="#the-solution" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>The solution</h2>

<h3><a id="user-content-in-the-next-few-lectures-well-talk-about-why-this-is-the-solution" class="anchor" href="#in-the-next-few-lectures-well-talk-about-why-this-is-the-solution" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" role="img" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1h-1c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5s1.55-3.5 3-3.5h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-0.91 2.72-2 3.25v-1.16c0.58-0.45 1-1.27 1-2.09 0-1.28-1.02-2.5-2-2.5H4c-0.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5s1 2.5 2 2.5z m9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5s-1.02 2.5-2 2.5H9c-0.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-0.83 0.42-1.64 1-2.09v-1.16c-1.09 0.53-2 1.84-2 3.25 0 1.81 1.55 3.5 3 3.5h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5s-1.5-3.5-3-3.5z"></path></svg></a>In the next few lectures we'll talk about why this is the solution</h3>

<span class="pl-smi">freqData</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">child</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> as.numeric(as.character(<span class="pl-smi">freqData</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">child</span>))
